clusters.title: ‘He’s blacked out’: Demolition derby car ploughs into crowd at NSW show
clusters.neutral_headline: Car Crashes into Crowd at NSW Demolition Derby
bullet_summary: Reported by The Age, ABC News Australia, 9News

items.title: ‘He’s blacked out’: Demolition derby car ploughs into crowd at NSW show
items.standfirst: Terrifying footage shows the car crashing through a fence and hitting spectators at a showground in NSW, injuring 13 people.
items.content: Terrifying footage shows the car crashing through a fence and hitting spectators at a showground in NSW, injuring 13 people.

items.title: Demolition derby crash victims in 'stable' conditions
items.standfirst: Six of 13 patients remain in hospital after a derby car crashed into a grandstand full of spectators at a Walcha council-run rally on Saturday night.
items.content: Six of 13 patients remain in hospital after a derby car crashed into a grandstand full of spectators at a Walcha council-run rally on Saturday night.

items.title: Two men fighting for life after car ploughed into crowd during demolition derby
items.standfirst: NSW Ambulance told 9News that 13 people had been injured, including two critical patients and six in a serious but stable condition.
items.content: More than a dozen people have been injured in an accident during a demolition derby in NSW.Two people are fighting for their lives after a car ploughed through a fence and into spectators at the Walcha Motorcycle Rally in Walcha, 420 kilometres north of Sydney, about 6.20pm yesterday evening.NSW Ambulance told 9News 13 people had been injured, including two critical patients and six in a serious but stable condition.READ MORE: Teen charged after pregnant woman and unborn baby die in Sydney crashA further five people remain in a stable condition.Two Westpac Rescue Helicopters were tasked by NSW Ambulance to attend the scene.Some of the injured parties have been transported to John Hunter Hospital.Among those hurt is a 54-year-old man who was left with spinal injuries and a man in his 30s who suffered head injuries.They were treated at the scene before being taken to John Hunter for further treatment.Police said the car had been competing in a race when it crashed through a fence and hit a mobile grandstand.They said officers had been told the 27-year-old driver was involved in an on-track collision immediately before his vehicle crashed through the fence.NSW MP Brendan Moylan said the vehicle had been taking part in a demolition derby as part of the Walcha Motorcycle Rally."Thank you so much to the ambos, the police, the SES and everyone involved for their swift and incredibly professional work at the scene," Moylan said in a post on Facebook."Like all of us, my thoughts are with everyone affected."The Crash Investigation Unit will examine the scene later today.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: A car crashed into spectators at a demolition derby in NSW.
The car crashed through a fence at a showground.
Thirteen people were injured in the incident.
Two individuals are in critical condition.
Six people remain hospitalized in stable condition.

items.content: Dozens of firefighters are battling a blaze at a furniture factory in Sydney's west. Emergency services were called to a fire on Park Road and Rose Crescent in Regents Park about 2.30pm today.A total of 40 crews and 12 trucks are there.READ MORE: One state to swelter through the hottest day in over a year tomorrow Fire and Rescue NSW Superintendent Adam Dewberry said crews are currently trying to control the fire, and it is too early to say why it started."The situation is ongoing and developing," he said."We'll get the fire out first before we start to have a look at where and how it started."Police, paramedics and the energy authority are also on scene.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. clusters.title: Fourth case of measles confirmed after Jelly Roll concert
clusters.neutral_headline: Measles Outbreak Widens After Concert
bullet_summary: Authorities say a case had been identified in the Logan region after three cases linked to the concert at the Brisbane Entertainment Centre on October 24 were confirmed on Wednesday
Health authorities confirmed a fourth infected person had attended the Jelly Roll concert in Brisbane

items.title: Fourth case of measles confirmed after Jelly Roll concert
items.standfirst: Authorities say a case had been identified in the Logan region after three cases linked to the concert at the Brisbane Entertainment Centre on October 24 were confirmed on Wednesday.
items.content: Authorities say a case had been identified in the Logan region after three cases linked to the concert at the Brisbane Entertainment Centre on October 24 were confirmed on Wednesday.

items.title: Outbreak of highly infectious disease widens after rapper's Aussie concert
items.standfirst: Health authorities confirmed a fourth infected person had attended the Jelly Roll concert in Brisbane.
items.content: Queensland's measles outbreak has widened after health authorities confirmed a fourth infected person had attended the Jelly Roll concert.Metro South Public Health Unit said the person did not know they were infected when they saw the American rapper perform at the Brisbane Entertainment Centre on October 24.They then visited the Mustang Brothers Football Club on November 8, Mullein Pharmacy Hillcrest on November 12, and Logan Hospital Emergency Department on November 12 and 14.READ MORE: The political scandal every Australian PM could be at risk of repeatingThree more infected concertgoers were also found to have spent time in the Gold Coast, Brisbane and Wide Bay areas.Health authorities are conducting contact tracing and will notify anyone who may have been exposed, but urged others who visited the same locations to monitor for symptoms.The warning comes just days after a Queenslander unknowingly infected with measles visited several locations during their travel to Sydney.They attended the Oasis concert at ACCOR Stadium on November 8 , as well as the Sydney Airport, CBD, Inner West and trains on November 8 and 10.NSW Health has consequently also issued a measles alert. "It's important for people to stay vigilant if they've been exposed, and if they develop symptoms, to please call ahead to their GP or emergency department to ensure they do not spend time in the waiting room with other patients," Health Protection NSW Executive Director Dr Jeremy McAnulty said.READ MORE: Multiple hurt, man fighting for life after speedway car hits crowdTens of thousands are estimated to have attended the Jelly Roll and Oasis concerts.Measles, a highly contagious infection that can lead to a red spotty rash, fever, cough, runny nose and sore eyes, can begin to present itself between 10 to 18 days from the time of contact.Anyone who believes they may be infected should avoid public spaces and get tested. NSW and Queensland health authorities are using the recent cases of measles to remind the public, particularly children and those aged 60 or under, to ensure they are vaccinated against the preventable disease. The full list of exact exposure times has been published on the Queensland Health and NSW Health websites. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: A fourth case of measles was confirmed.
The infected person attended a Jelly Roll concert.
The concert took place in Brisbane on October 24.
Three previous cases were linked to the concert.
Health authorities are monitoring the outbreak.

clusters.title: What France's famous cave replicas can teach Australia about rebuilding lost heritage
clusters.neutral_headline: France's Cave Replicas Offer Lessons for Australian Heritage

items.title: What France's famous cave replicas can teach Australia about rebuilding lost heritage
items.standfirst: Five years after Rio Tinto destroyed a 47,000-year-old sacred rock shelter to expand an iron ore mine, an ambitious rebuild is underway drawing inspiration all the way from France.
